or.translation[0].definitions[0].definit: used between two words or phrases to show that either of two things is possible, or used before the last in a list of possibilities or choices
or.translation[0].definitions[0].example: Shall we go out to the cinema or stay at home?
You can have ham, cheese, or tuna.
Grapes are usually either green or red.
He’s going to do it whether we like it or not.
You must do the job yourself or else employ someone else to do it.
Would you like a coffee or something?
She wasn’t involved in drugs or anything like that.
or.translation[0].definitions[1].definit: used after a negative verb when you mean not one thing and also not another thing
or.translation[0].definitions[1].example: He doesn’t have a television or a video.
Sonia never cleans or even offers to wash the dishes.
or.translation[0].definitions[2].definit: used to say that something bad could happen if someone does not do a particular thing
or.translation[0].definitions[2].example: Wear your coat or you’ll catch cold.
Hurry up or we’ll be late.
I had to defend myself or else he’d have killed me.
You’d better hand over the money, or else (=used to threaten someone).
or.translation[0].definitions[3].definit: used to correct something that you have said or to give more specific information
or.translation[0].definitions[3].example: It’s going to snow tomorrow, or that’s what the forecast says.
John picked us up in his car, or rather his dad’s car which he’d borrowed.
We’ve cleaned it all up, or at least most of it.
or.translation[0].definitions[4].definit: used to prove that something must be true, by saying that the situation would be different if it was not true
or.translation[0].definitions[4].example: He must be at home, or his car wouldn’t be here.
It’s obviously not urgent or else they would have called us straight away.
or.translation[0].definitions[5].definit: used to show that you are guessing at an amount or number because you cannot be exact
or.translation[0].definitions[5].example: The boy was three or four years of age.
I saw Donald leaving a minute or two ago.
There’s a motel a mile or so down the road  (=about a mile or possibly a little more).
or.translation[0].note_box[0].sections[0: used between two possibilities or choices, or before the last one in a list of possibilities or choices
Don’t get the chemicals on your hands or your clothes.
Payment can be made by cash, cheque  or  credit card.
used when giving another choice apart from the one you have already mentioned
Use a pair of scissors or, alternatively, a very sharp knife.
You can go up into the mountains. Alternatively, you can stroll around one of Switzerland’s delightful cities.
on the one had ... on the other (hand)
used when giving two very different ideas or opinions about something, especially when they need to be balanced against each other
On the one hand, I don’t want to hurt his feelings, but on the other, I don’t want to be miserable for the rest of my life.
or.translation[1].definitions[0].definit: someone who does something or is doing something
